Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the client’s email blinking insistently in my inbox. They wanted clarification on a line item from their latest invoice, and I knew I needed to respond quickly and professionally—my job as an accountant depended on it. At the same time, my phone buzzed nonstop. The post I’d made about our environmental campaign was going viral, and people were asking questions, hungry for more information. This was the moment I’d been waiting for as an activist—the perfect chance to educate and inspire the community. But the pressure was suffocating. If I ignored the client, I risked damaging a professional relationship and possibly my reputation at work. If I missed this surge of interest online, the momentum for our cause could fade. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between drafting a careful, detailed email and composing a passionate, informative comment. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, and I felt paralyzed, caught between two sets of expectations that seemed impossible to meet at once.
